GameDBLocalizedString.Text: Dental Caries
A progressive destruction of hard tooth tissue caused by bacteria, commonly known as a "cavity".
Impacted Wisdom Tooth
The third molar (wisdom tooth) fails to fully erupt into the dental arch due to lack of space, abnormal position, or other obstructions.
Pericoronitis
Inflammation and infection of the soft tissue (gingival flap) surrounding the crown of a partially erupted wisdom tooth.
Maxillofacial Space Infection
Infection originating from the oral cavity that spreads into the potential fascial spaces of the face and neck, forming cellulitis or abscess.
Osteomyelitis of the Jaw
Inflammatory reaction of the bone, bone marrow, and periosteum of the jaw, which can lead to bone tissue necrosis and destruction.
Sialolithiasis
Formation of calcified stones within the salivary gland ducts or glands, obstructing saliva flow and often causing swelling and pain during meals.
Mucocele
A cystic lesion formed by the extravasation of mucus into the surrounding tissues due to a ruptured minor salivary gland duct, commonly found on the lower lip.
Ranula
A mucocele of the sublingual gland, presenting as a bluish, cystic swelling on one side of the floor of the mouth.
Radicular Cyst
A cyst formed from epithelial proliferation stimulated by chronic inflammation of the periapical tissues due to pulp necrosis.
Dentigerous Cyst
An odontogenic cyst that encloses the crown of an unerupted tooth, developing from the reduced enamel epithelium.
Mandibular Prognathism
A jaw deformity characterized by the excessive forward growth of the mandible relative to the maxilla or cranial base, resulting in an "underbite".
Maxillary Prognathism
A jaw deformity characterized by the excessive forward growth of the maxilla relative to the mandible or cranial base, resulting in "buck teeth".
Micrognathia
Underdevelopment of the mandible, resulting in a short and recessed chin that affects the facial profile and function.
Mandibular Deviation
Asymmetrical development of the two sides of the mandible, causing the chin midline to deviate and resulting in facial asymmetry.
Temporomandibular Disorder (TMD)
A general term for a series of functional or pathological problems affecting the temporomandibular joint, masticatory muscles, and related structures.
TMJ Dislocation
The mandibular condyle slips out of the articular fossa and cannot be repositioned spontaneously, leaving the patient unable to close their mouth.
Trigeminal Neuralgia
Recurrent, brief, electric shock-like, severe pain in the distribution area of the trigeminal nerve, often with trigger points.
Cheilitis
A general term for various inflammatory diseases of the lips, characterized by redness, swelling, dryness, scaling, and chapping.
Glossitis
Inflammatory lesion of the tongue, which may manifest as tongue pain, swelling, color changes, and atrophy of the papillae.
Periodontitis
A chronic infectious disease of the periodontal supporting tissues (gingiva, periodontal ligament, alveolar bone) caused by dental plaque, which can lead to tooth loosening and loss.
Gingivitis
Inflammation confined to the gingival tissues, characterized by red, swollen, and easily bleeding gums, but without affecting the deeper periodontal tissues.
Recurrent Aphthous Ulcer
Recurrent, painful, round or oval ulcers on the oral mucosa, characterized by self-healing and periodic recurrence.
Sj√∂gren's Syndrome
A chronic autoimmune disease primarily affecting exocrine glands, typically manifesting as dry mouth and dry eyes.
Macroglossia
Abnormally large tongue volume, which can affect speech, swallowing, and breathing functions.
Ankyloglossia
Congenital abnormality of the lingual frenulum, causing it to be too short or thick, thereby restricting normal tongue movement.
Hemifacial Atrophy
A rare, progressive disease causing atrophy of the skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone on one side of the face.
Odontogenic Keratocyst
An odontogenic cyst with specific histological features (keratinized lining), which is aggressive in growth and has a high recurrence rate.
Calcifying Odontogenic Cyst
A rare odontogenic lesion histologically characterized by the presence of "ghost cells" and varying degrees of calcification.
Glandular Odontogenic Cyst
A rare, locally aggressive odontogenic cyst that histologically shows glandular differentiation features.
Primordial Cyst
A cyst formed by liquefaction degeneration of the stellate reticulum of a tooth germ before tooth development, typically occupying a space where a tooth should have been.
Lateral Periodontal Cyst
A non-inflammatory odontogenic cyst located on the lateral aspect of the root of a vital tooth.
Nasopalatine Duct Cyst
The most common non-odontogenic cyst, occurring within the incisive canal of the maxilla.
Globulomaxillary Cyst
A fissural cyst located between the maxillary lateral incisor and canine, often appearing as an inverted pear shape on radiographs.
Median Palatal Cyst
A rare non-odontogenic cyst occurring at the midline of the hard palate.
Median Mandibular Cyst
A rare non-odontogenic cyst occurring at the midline of the mandibular symphysis.
Dermoid Cyst
A cyst containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles, sebaceous glands), often occurring in the floor of the mouth in the maxillofacial region.
Epidermoid Cyst
A cyst with a wall composed of epidermis but without skin appendages, with contents of keratin.
Branchial Cleft Cyst
A congenital cyst arising from the incomplete regression of embryonic branchial arch structures, commonly located on the lateral side of the neck.
Thyroglossal Duct Cyst
A congenital cyst arising from the incomplete regression of the embryonic thyroglossal duct, commonly located in the midline of the neck.
Disc Displacement
Abnormal position of the articular disc within the temporomandibular joint, which can lead to joint clicking, pain, or limited mouth opening.
Ankylosis of TMJ
Severe limitation of mandibular movement, or even complete inability to open the mouth, due to fibrous or bony adhesion within the joint.
Myofascial Pain Syndrome
Localized pain in the masticatory muscles and fascia, with the presence of "trigger points" that can cause referred pain.
